body: Not trying to take a stance here, but are you calling the naming of alt accounts "actual doxxing", or am I blind and missed something? Honestly, it seems like a very loose application of the term to me, potentially more-so than the first - I can definitely see cases where a public name still shouldn't go viral, like when a false accusation makes it into the local newspaper.

body:
> are you calling the naming of alt accounts "actual doxxing", or am I blind and missed something?

Yes I am, because that is supposed to be private information. The admins have a list of alts for each user, and there's a reason that list isn't public: because this is an *anonymous* website. So yes, I'd call it doxxing for the admins to announce that in public, especially when it's just to get revenge on a user they don't like.

In contrast, the person jason "doxxed" posted their own name all over twitter and social media. It's not like someone maliciously gathered that personal information or anything, it was publicly available. From what I've heard, it was similar to the DGK ban where the admins were just looking for excuses to ban him because they hate him. Some of the admins hate me too, but fortunately they've decided to make me their "proof" of tolerance, so I'm probably okay for the time being.
body_html:
are you calling the naming of alt accounts "actual doxxing", or am I blind and missed something?

Yes I am, because that is supposed to be private information. The admins have a list of alts for each user, and there's a reason that list isn't public: because this is an anonymous website. So yes, I'd call it doxxing for the admins to announce that in public, especially when it's just to get revenge on a user they don't like.

In contrast, the person jason "doxxed" posted their own name all over twitter and social media. It's not like someone maliciously gathered that personal information or anything, it was publicly available. From what I've heard, it was similar to the DGK ban where the admins were just looking for excuses to ban him because they hate him. Some of the admins hate me too, but fortunately they've decided to make me their "proof" of tolerance, so I'm probably okay for the time being.

body: You’re stretching the definition of doxxing, no information that could link back to their real life was revealed. Admins have the ability to check if a user has alt accounts so people can’t bypass the 10 user GM limit, if you understand that this a ToS violation then you know the reason why they have the tool to do so. Ruqqus has very few rules compared to other sites, you have to actively go out your way to break them.

body:
I haven't seen admins solely take feedback from certain users, yes there are a group of test users that give feedback but everyone else is allowed to give feedback

There have been multiple changes due to users asking admins to change them, not all feedback is being paid attention to of course because the admins are working on Vue as well as other things.  IMO the admins need improvement on moderation and being more clear about the rules(but to be fair the ToS is very loose and there's a large potential for loopholes) but they've done very well at taking feedback from users, you just can't expect them to answer every single thread and idea when some of them aren't possible until Vue or are already being worked on for Vue but admins don't want to spoil.

body: Admins can have their own guilds, but I find it funny how they only ever GM the same people all the time, and those people just so happen to be the exact same ones who get chosen for everything else like focus group and/or discord mod and even a scrapped junior admin status, who are the same people who can get away with bending or breaking the rules and getting special privileges and treatment, who are also the exact same people who get the most and best responses from the admins. And in the case of devs, they are the people who always get their pull requests merged almost immediately and more often, whereas everyone elses' sit for weeks or months. Hey that reminds me of another site with an alien logo that we used to use...

And in the case of devs, they are the people who always get their pull requests merged almost immediately and more often, whereas everyone elses' sit for weeks or months. Hey that reminds me of another site with an alien logo that we used to use...

body:
Have you thought that maybe the people who are picked to be GM of guilds, moderators on the discord server, and part of the focus group are people who the admins get along well with so it's easier to make progress?

I can't say much about the coding because I'm not in that area of Ruqqus or the discord but I know at least Seq communicates a LOT more with Cap about the requests and usually is right there when the merge happens in case of any instant issues.

I agree that the mods can bend or break the rules on the discord(fairly rarely) but I don't see the same type of things happening on Ruqqus.  Which as you said before, you can't use discord that often, so you're unable to communicate with the admins much outside of Ruqqus or Github and with the admins probably getting dozens of pings a day on Ruqqus the lack of communication might be a core issue.

body:
> Have you thought that maybe the people who are picked to be GM of guilds, moderators on the discord server, and part of the focus group are people who the admins get along well with so it's easier to make progress?

Yes, it seems the admins just randomly decide some people are better than everyone else and get divine status. The fact that they let those users do everything and absolutely *refuse* to even consider letting someone else do just one of those things is what's so concerning. It's starting to resemble DefaultMods and I don't like it.

> I agree that the mods can bend or break the rules on the discord(fairly rarely)

It's not rare. They break the rules all the time, and they have zero restrictions either (no word filter, no slowmode, no having to earn roles to enter gated channels). This is definitely abused, and the admins are super strict about everyone else following them but completely okay with mods doing whatever the hell they want. And everyone else worships this setup, it's a huge circlejerk.

> Which as you said before, you can't use discord that often, so you're unable to communicate with the admins much outside of Ruqqus or Github and with the admins probably getting dozens of pings a day on Ruqqus the lack of communication might be a core issue.

Which is exactly why the admins need to actually spend more time on ruqqus rather than discord. I don't even see why they have to be the ones running that, someone else could and it would both ease their workload and open up opportunities for more than one server.
body_html:
Have you thought that maybe the people who are picked to be GM of guilds, moderators on the discord server, and part of the focus group are people who the admins get along well with so it's easier to make progress?

Yes, it seems the admins just randomly decide some people are better than everyone else and get divine status. The fact that they let those users do everything and absolutely refuse to even consider letting someone else do just one of those things is what's so concerning. It's starting to resemble DefaultMods and I don't like it.

I agree that the mods can bend or break the rules on the discord(fairly rarely)

It's not rare. They break the rules all the time, and they have zero restrictions either (no word filter, no slowmode, no having to earn roles to enter gated channels). This is definitely abused, and the admins are super strict about everyone else following them but completely okay with mods doing whatever the hell they want. And everyone else worships this setup, it's a huge circlejerk.

Which as you said before, you can't use discord that often, so you're unable to communicate with the admins much outside of Ruqqus or Github and with the admins probably getting dozens of pings a day on Ruqqus the lack of communication might be a core issue.

Which is exactly why the admins need to actually spend more time on ruqqus rather than discord. I don't even see why they have to be the ones running that, someone else could and it would both ease their workload and open up opportunities for more than one server.

body: It's the same though.  Admins would rather have people they can talk to in private over issues so they can't easily be exploited and can get instant replies back.  Ruqqus doesn't have an instant reply chat yet so it's harder to communicate and get instant feedback.  Discord is currently the best alternative until that issue is settled so it makes a lot of sense that people that are able to use discord are the ones the admins look to for feedback and issue solving.  If people posted bugs and issues they found on Ruqqus there is a good chance someone will actively try to find that bug before it is patched, causing the admins to do massive amounts of cleanup.

I mean the same thing applies with the instant reply chat, it's quicker and easier to reply on discord than on Ruqqus so the issue gets solved MUCH faster.  Admins allowed people to GM certain(non-ruqqus) guilds with them because they were in an instant reply chat and could talk easily.

I wouldn't let someone GM a guild if they weren't on discord ATM because if there's an issue I want to be able to get instant replies and be able to contact them easily, and without a proper Ruqqus app with push notifications, it's hard to do that on Ruqqus.  Sentient added me as a GM to +RuqqusDiscord while he's been busy because I'm in the discord and he was able to DM me about it.  I added Friday as a GM to +Inspirational_Opossum because they're able to DM me on discord.  So I fully understand admins turning to people who are able to instantly get and reply to messages over someone they would have to babysit Ruqqus for.

body:
> but dyno is a bitch about that so it's hard to set up.

That's not the only thing though:

* Slowmode

* Ability to participate in gated channels they haven't earned the rules for

* Admins let them break the rules a lot

* Admins put their names at the very top of the server

* Admins listen to them more and have a private chat room with them

* Admins originally planned on making them junior admins on the actual site too

* Admins only let them GM their guilds or basically anything.

* Most of them were let into the focus group.

> I've only seen Angst and Megu get "special treatment" on Ruqqus as a discord mod

And is that not a problem to you?

> Seq gets "special treatment" but that's because he constantly works with Cap on issues and became a mod after he had helped so much.

Cap doesn't just let anyone help him. He only picks a few people he thinks are "worthy" enough and everyone else is pretty much warded off.

> Ruq, Luk, Nova, or Sentient

Luk is a GM on +technology and a discord mod. Ruq is part of the focus group and a discord mod. I believe Nova and/or Sentient GM a guild or two as well.

> But the "special treatment" on Ruqqus just seems to be that they're allowed to GM alongside the admins, which I see no issues with.

And the other things I listed. But just the fact that they always pick the exact same people for everything hints that they are extremely biased and respecters of persons and are starting to form a DefaultMods-like mindset.
body_html:
but dyno is a bitch about that so it's hard to set up.

That's not the only thing though:

  • Slowmode

  • Ability to participate in gated channels they haven't earned the rules for

  • Admins let them break the rules a lot

  • Admins put their names at the very top of the server

  • Admins listen to them more and have a private chat room with them

  • Admins originally planned on making them junior admins on the actual site too

  • Admins only let them GM their guilds or basically anything.

  • Most of them were let into the focus group.

I've only seen Angst and Megu get "special treatment" on Ruqqus as a discord mod

And is that not a problem to you?

Seq gets "special treatment" but that's because he constantly works with Cap on issues and became a mod after he had helped so much.

Cap doesn't just let anyone help him. He only picks a few people he thinks are "worthy" enough and everyone else is pretty much warded off.

Ruq, Luk, Nova, or Sentient

Luk is a GM on +Technology and a discord mod. Ruq is part of the focus group and a discord mod. I believe Nova and/or Sentient GM a guild or two as well.

But the "special treatment" on Ruqqus just seems to be that they're allowed to GM alongside the admins, which I see no issues with.

And the other things I listed. But just the fact that they always pick the exact same people for everything hints that they are extremely biased and respecters of persons and are starting to form a DefaultMods-like mindset.

body:
1. I agree with you on the slowmode and dyno(the only rules/limits I've seen them "break")
2. They have to be allowed into gated channels in order to moderate those channels
3. Admins names are at the top of the server so users know who to report bugs to and DM for issues/exploits
4. Of course they listen to the "6-8 people" more they're trusted users
5. They need a private chat room to talk about strikes and bans, users would get upset if mods talked about banning someone or new rules being made in the open
6. The "junior admins" would've just been moderators to the site which will be a needed thing in the future *anyways*
7. The focus group is a group of users able to quickly reply to changes that the admins trust to be unbias and honest, it will grow with time and I see 0 issues with the admins having a focus group of their choosing
8. The only "special treatment" on Ruqqus you've given me is that they were picked as GMs on admin's(mainly kek) guilds.  I don't see this as a problem whatsoever, GMs are able to choose who they want to be GMs alongside them so admins should be allowed to do the same.  They won't be able to make default mods with this they just want to be able to have their own guilds with people they trust taking care of them.
9. I can't say very much about the coding but again, communication has a lot to do with it.  Seq is probably the one most in touch with the admins over issues so I can see why he's the go-to but again, I can't say much because I don't know coding and I've only looked at github once before realizing I had no clue what 90% of the stuff on there was

I don't see this as a problem whatsoever, GMs are able to choose who they want to be GMs alongside them so admins should be allowed to do the same. They won't be able to make default mods with this they just want to be able to have their own guilds with people they trust taking care of them.
  9. I can't say very much about the coding but again, communication has a lot to do with it. 1. -

2. They don't have to have permission to send messages, just delete them. Actually since it's a gated channel it shouldn't need as much moderation as the regular channels, the admins could just do it. Regardless they shouldn't be allowed to abuse this, which they clearly are and do.

3. -

4. Yeah, remind me where that got reddit again?

5. No, they discuss other stuff too like roles, rules, and ideas, stuff that should be public. Not just bans. And they should just DM an admin if they need clarification on that. They also shouldn't be allowed to see deleted and pre-edited messages, I don't think even the admins should let alone the mods. Also the audit log is transparent to the mods but no one else can see it, it should transparent to everyone.

6. Yeah, and you have *no problem* at all with us doing *Exactly* the same powermod-admin cabal setup that reddit had?

7. It's the fact that most of them are also chosen for everything else

8. It shows their bias and cliqueiness. I don't trust it when admins act like that, because we all know what that leads to.

9. -

3. Admins names are at the top of the server so users know who to report bugs to and DM for issues/exploits
4. Of course they listen to the "6-8 people" more they're trusted users
5. They need a private chat room to talk about strikes and bans, users would get upset if mods talked about banning someone or new rules being made in the open
6. The "junior admins" would've just been moderators to the site which will be a needed thing in the future *anyways*
7. The focus group is a group of users able to quickly reply to changes that the admins trust to be unbias and honest, it will grow with time and I see 0 issues with the admins having a focus group of their choosing
8. The only "special treatment" on Ruqqus you've given me is that they were picked as GMs on admin's(mainly kek) guilds.  I don't see this as a problem whatsoever, GMs are able to choose who they want to be GMs alongside them so admins should be allowed to do the same.  They won't be able to make default mods with this they just want to be able to have their own guilds with people they trust taking care of them.
9. I can't say very much about the coding but again, communication has a lot to do with it.  Seq is probably the one most in touch with the admins over issues so I can see why he's the go-to but again, I can't say much because I don't know coding and I've only looked at github once before realizing I had no clue what 90% of the stuff on there was

body:
1. No, you have to earn some of them. Same with some of the theory channels and other stuff.

2. No, it got that way because the admins became friends with a particular clique of users and made them the moderators of every subreddit. There was a time when the only subreddits were the defaults. Take a look at the moderators of subreddits like /r/help, it's the exact same thing they're doing on ruqqus.

3. If a user fixes a message then it's fixed, why does it need modding? And *maybe* the admins should be able to see deleted and pre-edited messages, but definitely not mods because they're just regular users, or should be even though the admins treat them as special.

4. "Guild limits" isn't going to stop anything. These power user cabals work together. They will simply spread GM duties across multiple people. Plus it just shows that the admins are biased and can't be trusted to make objective decisions.

5. How so? What's so wrong about literally everyone on the site other than 6-8 users?

6. No they're not, because it's a completely unfair system *and* it will result in the same future as reddit. Do you really want ruqqus to just half fix exactly *one* problem reddit has and keep all the rest?
